you _can_ use it for database connections because all of your information is in there
you have to use it for seeds and migrations
you _can_ use the `knexfile.js` for the database config information on both of them, but you by no means have to
Likewise, you can use knex for an express project where you did migrations and seeds with SQL, or any other tool
you could use knex for migrations and seeds on a Java project, or a Ruby project, or anything you want. Does not need to be a javascript app, much less an express app.
The migrations and seeds thing and the database connection thing are completely separate
remember! `knex` is TWO TOOLS!
you need it in the `app.js` for your application to use `process.env` for anything other than db calls
you need it in the `knex.js` file to run migrations and seeds

messages.text: <@U2MLLCBCY> the solution is CASCADE. It is worth reading up on it.  <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14182079/delete-rows-with-foreign-key-in-postgresql>
A solution I tried was starting the a_table seed file by clearing out b_table `knex('b_table').del()` couldn't get it to work though
So you actually need to clear out b_table first. But seed it last.
The problem is that at the beginning of your seed file, you delete all the contents of the table. That means a_table is cleared out first, which violates all the a_table.id references in b_table.

The problem is that each seed file starts with the deletion of the corresponding table. So here's an example:
b_table has a foreign key that references a_table.
now the seed file for a_table will run first, which is good because otherwise b_table, when it's seeded, would have values referencing a_table.id that didn't exist yet.

messages.text: `returning` is an extension to SQL that is non-standard.  That the Knex Query Lab is not showing it, may be a problem with the KQL.  How I would test it in your program by adding a `.then()` to the Promise that Knex returns to you, and printing out its results.

file.title: Migration files
file.preview:
1. Create a migration file for each table
2. Once migrated, DO NOT change these files
3. Want to add a new constraint onto an existing table?  Put that in  a new migration file with a new timestamp in the name.

just wanted to shoot out a never mind on this. In case any of you run into it as well I'll give a tl;dr on why for me it wasn't a good idea.
 
I only found myself in need of a require in client side code because I was trying to do things from the browser that I really should be doing from the server. Secret things. There are options that allow us to do it anyway (browserify, webpack, component, requireJS), but I haven't found a good reason to do that, and I've found a few reasons not to. Mainly servers are good at keeping secrets. Clients are built not to keep secrets. A lot of what we do with APIs involve secrets. We should work with the secrets on the server.

trying to work some node on a project and when I ran into the fact that `require` is not defined I went down a circuitous rabbit hole. Long story short, I'm wary of leveraging a third(ish) party(ish) implementation on CommonJS like component or webpack because I have a suspicion that we will be going a different route in the course. Would any of you instructor/resident types want to shed any light on the route we're taking so I can go that way?

<@U2P2J8AHK> the module.exports can export a value, a function, or an object, or what was a returned by another function (and this return could also be a value, a function, or an object).  Basically, it exports whatever you want.  The important thing is that it exports what you need it to export to make sense for your module.

Random potential help: I was re-reading up on express/node and realized that I presumed the module.exports function was exporting a function, but it is ACTUALLY exporting the return of the function. The object.  Potato patohtoe…  If I can help just one g-41er, my work will be done :xmastree:

messages.text: The next time you see someone being an asshole about the difference between an "engineer" and a "programmer", that's what they're talking about.
But it's a skill, and it's necessary, and you signed up to learn how to get better at it. The _real_ value is identifying the input/output bit, and _then_ being able to implement it.
The "programming"- how the transformation happens- is almost always the last interesting part.
You cannot make a useful system without knowing what the inputs and outputs should be.
What the system does is transform the zip code into the graph
I give a system my zip code, and it gives me a data visualization of the incomes in it
A system takes inputs and transforms them into outputs
Every solution is a system

When I went through the git tutorial I initially added that nasa/astronaut-marooned.git as my origin repo. So when I tried to run push I got that error because that's not a real repo I have access to. 

When I realized I needed to set my origin to the actual repo I just created on  GitHub, I got the second error.

To discover the error I ran

git remote -v 

That showed me what my origin was set to:

origin	git@github.com:nasa/marooned-astronaut.git (fetch)
origin	git@github.com:nasa/marooned-astronaut.git (push)

to fix that I ran 

git remote rm origin

to remove the origin and then set it back to the repo I had created in GitHub

git remote add origin git@github.com:benflock/example.com

then I had to set it as my upstream branch (which may or may not have been the correct thing to do. I didn't see it in the tutorial)

git push --set-upstream branch origin master
